input: I was thinking about a loyalty program app for existing customers.
answer: Good start! A loyalty app can strengthen retention if it offers clear, tangible value. Try to 1) define the main benefit, 2) identify your core audience, and 3) decide whether it integrates with existing tools or stands alone. Focus on solving a real customer frustration, not just rewarding points. What specific behavior do you want to encourage with this app—repeat purchases, referrals, or feedback?

input: I want to automate part of our bug-reporting workflow.
answer: That’s a great proactive idea. To make it convincing, outline: 1) the exact manual steps now, 2) where automation saves the most time, and 3) how it reduces mistakes. Start with a simple script that logs data automatically, then measure time saved. When proposing to your lead, frame it in terms of business value, not just convenience. What evidence can you collect this week to show current delays or pain points?

input: I get nervous when talking to new clients.
answer: Completely normal. Preparation reduces stress. Try this: 1) outline three open-ended questions about the client's goals, 2) practice your intro aloud, and 3) end meetings by summarizing key takeaways. Focus on listening, not selling. Write your first line now—how will you introduce yourself while keeping it conversational?

input: Clients keep changing their minds about details.
answer: That’s common. Set expectations early: 1) schedule one structured review round, 2) ask clients to group all feedback at once, and 3) confirm changes in writing before revising. Keep a ‘change log’ so both sides see history. What phrase could you use next time to politely close a feedback round?

input: Our backlog is overflowing and everyone says their item is urgent.
answer: You can bring order by using a scoring framework. Try: 1) Impact vs Effort, 2) Must-have vs Nice-to-have, 3) Business vs Technical debt. Start with rough estimates, then validate with leads. Visualizing priorities helps everyone see trade-offs. Can you pick three items and assign them impact-effort scores to start the discussion?

input: I feel like I’m doing everything myself.
answer: Classic founder trap! Step 1: list all recurring weekly tasks. Step 2: mark which truly require your decisions. Step 3: delegate one low-risk task this week with clear outcomes, not instructions. Check results, give feedback, and repeat. Who on your team could handle a task that drains your time but doesn’t need your signature?

input: We always underestimate development time.
answer: That’s solvable. After each sprint, record plan vs actual times for top tasks. Look for patterns—e.g., missing dependencies or review delays. Adjust future estimates by that margin. Also, ask devs what “unknowns” they fear before committing. Could you start logging actual vs planned time for the next sprint?
